div1.p: Hanson reports on yellow fever in Colombia. He also discusses financial matters.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, August 15, 1923
div1.opener:

JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, JR.

WILLIAM H. WELCH
EDWIN R. EMBREE
SECRETARY

ASSISTANT SECRETARY
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD
61 BROADWAY, NEW YORK
Bogata, Colombia.
August 15, 1923.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
We are still in Bogata, have been
here one week, and still have not gotten the things done in
which are necessary before going down into the fever section
Today is a “fiesta” and everything is closed up tight and no
one is to bee seen on business. We expected to get our arrange-
ments made with the Minister today so as to be able to pre-
sent all our wants to the President to-morrow, but I fear
that it is going to take another day now. However we will
get away from here on Saturday at the latest. As we go we
expect to look Girardot over as it is a town of consider-
able size, and the terminus of the river travel. Honda is
probably what might be called a key point in the upper river
but it does not have a very large population. It does have
a lot of transient population, i.e., travellers.

There are practically no confirmed reports coming
in at the present time, but one does hear rumors of sickness
in different points. When I came up the river I was told about
three or four deaths in Puerto Santos, some of which were
said to have had black vomit, there was also a report of cases
of pernicious fevers in Barranca Bermeja, notwithstanding the
fact that the physician of the Tropical Oil and the native
physician who was there denied anything suggestive of yellow
fever. As we go down the river we expect to spend one or two
days there looking up any case of suspicious illness which
may exist. There was also a report of suspicious cases of
illness at Puerto Wilches. As the situation appears to me
there is a probability of the fever walking down the river
to Barranquilla dn Cartagena, as all points with these rumors
are on the river and there are numerous villages along the
banks which can readily serve as relaying points.

The quarantine referred to by Dr. White is just so many
words and will have about the same effect inpreventing the
spread of the fever as our “Cordon Sanitario” in Peru.

Dr. Garcia Medina, the Director of Health, spoke very
highly of you and values your contributions to the subject
very highly. He appears to be a very fine man, quite a con-
trast to what we had to deal with in Peru. Our impressions
so far are that these Colombians are quite superior to the
Peruvians.

It is very evident however that it is going to be most
difficult to get about in this country. The transportation is
(so far as I can judge) much more difficult that that in Peru.

This difficulty in transportation however does not
prevent the peones from travelling from place to place, and
I consider them the principal conveyers of the disease from
one village or town to another. They go from one village to
another in canoes on the river, and from what I saw of the
river traffic I do not see any reason why the fever should
not get to Barranquilla and Cartagena. From the brief in-
vestigation made by Dunn and myself togather with the local
municipal Medicos, it seems that every house in Barranquilla
is breeding an abundance of Stegomyia. With such conditions
I do not feel that it is afe to leave these places without
cleaning them up. This especially in view of the fact that
Puerto Santos is quite some distance north of the Bucara-
manga region, and if it was yellow fever which they reported
to me they will certainly relay it down the river. El Banco
is a town on the river which has 5167 population, and is o
one of the main ports for the river traffic. Puerto Santos
is not far from Puerto Wilches, but is on the LeBrija river
and could easily carry infection down to Banco, which would
serve as an easy distributing point for the lower part of
the valley and to the larger coast towns and cities.

Calamar is another town on the river with over 6000
population and is only about six hours from Barranquilla
by steamer going down the river. What should be done with
these places I will not be able to decide until after the
investigation of the Bucaramanga sector, and the investigation
of these outside places which are said to have had cases. If
it proves true then in my opinion the only rational thing
to do will be to protect Cartagena, Barranquilla, Puerto
Colombia by doing stegomyia work there and at the same time
cleaning up the key points on the river, such as Calamar,
Banco, Puerto Berrio, Honda and Girardot, and also Barranca
Bermeja on account of the increasing activities there of the
Tropical Oil Co.,. I beleive this Magdelena section should
be organized before attempt to do anything in the Cucuta
section. If the fever came from there it has already spread
its seed. The communication between Cucuta and the Magdelena
sector is over the mountains and a most difficult
journey, henec of no importance as far as further propaga-
tion of the fever towards the west or north is concerned,
and is of less importance to Colombia than to Venezuela.

As soon as I have things running fairly satisfactorily
here I shall go to Cucuta either by the Bucaramanga route
or by sea via Maracaibo. One can make the trip from Barran-
quilla by sea in less time than over the mountains by the
Bucaramanga route.

This job is no flowery bed of roses. A man earns about
twice what he is paid for being here, and I certainly am not
going to invigle anybody else into this thing without insistin
on proper pay. Both Dunn and I are stung on the pay.
I have not heard a word from my folks since I left Sioux City.
With the kindest regards to Laura and yourself,

closer.salute: As ever your disciple and admirer,
